title: Functionality
text: NOTE: SCOs are named Units within the Self Serve Companion. When accessing the Self Serve Companion, you will find a list of all the Units that are currently online for your shop. In the context of the Self Serve Companion, a Unit is considered online when the SCO app is running inside a browser. It is important to note that if a machine is powered off, the browser is closed, or the browser is not on the SCO web page, the Unit will not be reported as online in the Self Serve Companion. Colour Coding The Self Serve Companion utilizes a basic color coding system that works in conjunction with the NCR SCO Tri-Light color system. Here's an overview of the color codes and their meanings: Green: This color indicates that there are no obstacles or issues preventing the user from completing a transaction smoothly. Orange/Amber: When a Unit is displayed in this color, it signifies that a supervisory action will be required soon in order for the customer to proceed with the transaction. Typically, this occurs when there is a need for approval due to a restricted item. Red: The red color indicates a hard block, meaning the customer cannot continue with the transaction at all. Immediate action is necessary to resolve the issue. In addition to the color coding, each Unit will present a message that provides further information to complement the status color. These messages serve to provide more context or details about the current status of the Unit. Status Messages Ready The Unit is ready for the next customer. No action is required. Needs Arm Setup The Unit in the Self Serve Companion will provide information about the status of the SCO's connector. Each SCO is expected to have one associated connector. If no connector is selected for an SCO, the Unit will indicate that it "Needs ARM Setup." For further details regarding the connector setup, you can refer to the POS Admin - K3 Connector Manager, which provides more comprehensive information on managing connectors in the system. Help When the customer presses the Help button, the SCO will be blocked and the Unit will show in Red. Item Not Found When a barcode is scanned that cannot be recognised, it will block the customer from proceeding so they do not accidentally add the item into their bag without paying. Restricted Items In the Product Configurator, items can be restricted in two ways. Firstly, an item can be flagged as "Age Restricted," which requires the clerk to determine if the customer is legally allowed to purchase the item based on their age. Secondly, the quantity of items that can be purchased together in a single transaction can be restricted using the "Restricted Quantity" field. When a restricted item is scanned, both the Tri Light and SCO Companion will display an orange status. This indicates that although it doesn't block the customer from proceeding with the transaction, it presents an opportunity for the clerk to remotely approve the restriction. By approving the restriction promptly, the clerk can facilitate a faster checkout process for the customer. If the clerk does not catch the orange alert in time, the SCO will block the transaction when the customer press the pay button and the SCO will force an authorisation. The clerk needs to press the Authorize button to remotely authorise the transaction.
description:
NOTE: SCOs are named Units within the Self Serve Companion.


When accessing the Self Serve Companion, you will find a list of all the Units that are currently online for your shop. In the context of the Self Serve Companion, a Unit is considered online when the SCO app is running inside a browser. It is important to note that if a machine is powered off, the browser is closed, or the browser is not on the SCO web page, the Unit will not be reported as online in the Self Serve Companion.



Colour Coding

The Self Serve Companion utilizes a basic color coding system that works in conjunction with the NCR SCO Tri-Light color system. Here's an overview of the color codes and their meanings:


Green: This color indicates that there are no obstacles or issues preventing the user from completing a transaction smoothly.


Orange/Amber: When a Unit is displayed in this color, it signifies that a supervisory action will be required soon in order for the customer to proceed with the transaction. Typically, this occurs when there is a need for approval due to a restricted item.


Red: The red color indicates a hard block, meaning the customer cannot continue with the transaction at all. Immediate action is necessary to resolve the issue.


In addition to the color coding, each Unit will present a message that provides further information to complement the status color. These messages serve to provide more context or details about the current status of the Unit.


Status Messages

Ready


The Unit is ready for the next customer. No action is required.



Needs Arm Setup

The Unit in the Self Serve Companion will provide information about the status of the SCO's connector. Each SCO is expected to have one associated connector. If no connector is selected for an SCO, the Unit will indicate that it "Needs ARM Setup." For further details regarding the connector setup, you can refer to the POS Admin - K3 Connector Manager, which provides more comprehensive information on managing connectors in the system.



Help

When the customer presses the Help button, the SCO will be blocked and the Unit will show in Red.



Item Not Found

When a barcode is scanned that cannot be recognised, it will block the customer from proceeding so they do not accidentally add the item into their bag without paying.



Restricted Items

In the Product Configurator, items can be restricted in two ways. Firstly, an item can be flagged as "Age Restricted," which requires the clerk to determine if the customer is legally allowed to purchase the item based on their age. Secondly, the quantity of items that can be purchased together in a single transaction can be restricted using the "Restricted Quantity" field.


When a restricted item is scanned, both the Tri Light and SCO Companion will display an orange status. This indicates that although it doesn't block the customer from proceeding with the transaction, it presents an opportunity for the clerk to remotely approve the restriction. By approving the restriction promptly, the clerk can facilitate a faster checkout process for the customer.



If the clerk does not catch the orange alert in time, the SCO will block the transaction when the customer press the pay button and the SCO will force an authorisation.



The clerk needs to press the Authorize button to remotely authorise the transaction.
